author: JuliaRegistrator

comments.body:
Your `new package` pull request does not meet all of the guidelines for automatic merging.

Specifically, your pull request does not meet the following guidelines:

- The following dependencies do not have a compat entry that has an upper bound: Conda, PyCall, PyPlot

If you want to prevent this pull request from being auto-merged, simply leave a comment.

(If you want to post a comment without blocking auto-merging, you must include the text `[noblock]` in your comment.)

---
It is important to note that if your pull request does not meet the guidelines for automatic merging, this does not mean that your pull request will never be merged. It just means that your pull request will require manual review by a human.

> These guidelines are intended not as requirements for packages but as very conservative guidelines, which, if your new package or new version of a package meets them, it may be automatically merged.

---
On a separate note, I see that you are registering a release with a version number of the form `v0.X.Y`.

Does your package have a stable public API? If so, then it's time for you to register version `v1.0.0` of your package. (This is not a requirement. It's just a recommendation.)

If your package does not yet have a stable public API, then of course you are not yet ready to release version `v1.0.0`.

---

[noblock]

The error message is correct. To see why, take the following steps:

1. Under the `Some checks were not successful` heading, in the `Travis CI - Pull Request` row, click on the `Details` link.
2. Scroll all the way to the bottom and click on `View more details on Travis CI`.
3. Click on the `Julia: 1.2` job.
4. Read the Travis logs. You may need to click the ▶ triangle in the left hand column in order to show hidden rows.

For example, in this case, look at the Travis logs starting at line 363. (Here is a link: https://travis-ci.com/JuliaRegistries/General/jobs/249652874#L363)

Here is what the logs say starting at line 363:
```
363[ Info: Successfully installed package
364[ Info: Attempting to import package
365ERROR: LoadError: InitError: PyError (PyImport_ImportModule
366
367The Python package matplotlib could not be found by pyimport. Usually this means
368that you did not install matplotlib in the Python version being used by PyCall.
369
370PyCall is currently configured to use the Python version at:
371
372/usr/bin/python3
373
374and you should use whatever mechanism you usually use (apt-get, pip, conda,
375etcetera) to install the Python package containing the matplotlib module.
376
377One alternative is to re-configure PyCall to use a different Python
378version on your system: set ENV["PYTHON"] to the path/name of the python
379executable you want to use, run Pkg.build("PyCall"), and re-launch Julia.
380
381Another alternative is to configure PyCall to use a Julia-specific Python
382distribution via the Conda.jl package (which installs a private Anaconda
383Python distribution), which has the advantage that packages can be installed
384and kept up-to-date via Julia.  As explained in the PyCall documentation,
385set ENV["PYTHON"]="", run Pkg.build("PyCall"), and re-launch Julia. Then,
386To install the matplotlib module, you can use `pyimport_conda("matplotlib", PKG)`,
387where PKG is the Anaconda package the contains the module matplotlib,
388or alternatively you can use the Conda package directly (via
389`using Conda` followed by `Conda.add` etcetera).
390
391) <class 'ImportError'>
392ImportError("No module named 'matplotlib'",)
393
394Stacktrace:
395 [1] pyimport(::String) at /tmp/jl_mgAz2i/packages/PyCall/ttONZ/src/PyCall.jl:544
396 [2] pyimport_conda(::String, ::String, ::String) at /tmp/jl_mgAz2i/packages/PyCall/ttONZ/src/PyCall.jl:702
397 [3] pyimport_conda at /tmp/jl_mgAz2i/packages/PyCall/ttONZ/src/PyCall.jl:701 [inlined]
398 [4] __init__() at /tmp/jl_mgAz2i/packages/PyPlot/4wzW1/src/init.jl:179
399 [5] _include_from_serialized(::String, ::Array{Any,1}) at ./loading.jl:685
400 [6] _require_from_serialized(::String) at ./loading.jl:736
401 [7] _require(::Base.PkgId) at ./loading.jl:1023
402 [8] require(::Base.PkgId) at ./loading.jl:911
403 [9] require(::Module, ::Symbol) at ./loading.jl:906
404 [10] include at ./boot.jl:328 [inlined]
405 [11] include_relative(::Module, ::String) at ./loading.jl:1094
406 [12] include(::Module, ::String) at ./Base.jl:31
407 [13] top-level scope at none:2
408 [14] eval at ./boot.jl:330 [inlined]
409 [15] eval(::Expr) at ./client.jl:432
410 [16] top-level scope at ./none:3
411during initialization of module PyPlot
412in expression starting at /tmp/jl_mgAz2i/packages/ClimateEasy/cKz0E/src/ClimateEasy.jl:13
413ERROR: Failed to precompile ClimateEasy [47ceb0c8-0fe6-4c49-a4a1-92bc59187c00] to /tmp/jl_mgAz2i/compiled/v1.2/ClimateEasy/E2jGb.ji.
414Stacktrace:
```

Your `new package` pull request does not meet all of the guidelines for automatic merging.

Specifically, your pull request does not meet the following guidelines:

- I was not able to install and import the package. See the Travis logs for details.

If you want to prevent this pull request from being auto-merged, simply leave a comment.

(If you want to post a comment without blocking auto-merging, you must include the text `[noblock]` in your comment.)

---
It is important to note that if your pull request does not meet the guidelines for automatic merging, this does not mean that your pull request will never be merged. It just means that your pull request will require manual review by a human.

> These guidelines are intended not as requirements for packages but as very conservative guidelines, which, if your new package or new version of a package meets them, it may be automatically merged.

On a separate note, I see that you are registering a release with a version number of the form `v0.X.Y`.

Does your package have a stable public API? If so, then it's time for you to register version `v1.0.0` of your package. (This is not a requirement. It's just a recommendation.)
